<@U1AU8DRQR>: I haven’t studied the newest release of the SDK, but this duplication should be expected to a degree based on what I know about the architecture
the reason is, the non-SDK path relies on an NVP to be considered part of “the client"
e.g.  [client: [app] -> [nvp]] -> [[vp][vp][vp]]]
what the SDK does is collapses that [client] box, so some functions that are done in the golang-based NVP are now done natively within client context
(rather than being tiered via REST)

    image: hyperledger/fabric-membersrvc
    ports:
      - "50051:50051"
    volumes: # docker.sock is mapped as the default CORE_VM_ENDPOINT
      - /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock
    command: membersrvc
    networks:
      - main

  vp0:
    image: hyperledger/fabric-peer
    ports:
      - "5000:5000"
      - "30303:30303"
      - "30304:30304"
    environment:
      - CORE_PEER_ADDRESSAUTODETECT=true
      - CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=unix:///var/run/docker.sock
      - CORE_LOGGING_LEVEL=DEBUG
      - CORE_PEER_ID=vp0
      - CORE_SECURITY_ENROLLID=test_vp0
      - CORE_SECURITY_ENROLLSECRET=MwYpmSRjupbT
    volumes: # docker.sock is mapped as the default CORE_VM_ENDPOINT
      - /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock
    networks:
      - main
    command: sh -c "sleep 5; peer node start”

networks:
  main:```
note the CORE_VM_ENDPOINT, but also the volume definition, that will allow the fabric within the container to reach the host’s docker process effectively...

<@U1PSHT5C4>: you don’t need the entire fabric repo to be vendored in your chaincode project. It doesn’t need to be vendored at all. What you do need is to have the core/chaincode/shim package in your $GOPATH to build your chaincode binary. You can accomplish this by cloning the gerrit repo into your $GOPATH until we have set up a means to tell go get how to resolve into Gerrit.
cd $GOPATH/src
mkdir -p <http://github.com/hyperledger/|github.com/hyperledger/>
cd <http://github.com/hyperledger|github.com/hyperledger>
git clone <http://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/fabric>
that should do the trick
also, you might want to start using the fabric-chaintool - it’s actually pretty cool
until we have the docs hosted by LF, you can find the latest here <http://cbf-fabric-docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/Chaincode-setup/#running-the-chaincode>

Hi <@U0KPFAZNF>. The issue you are observing, related to the above error as well as to the locking errors, has been introduced within the past several days. I am not 100% sure which change did it, but it modified the Vagrant setup such that some of the permissions on the ~/.npm/ folder have changed. Specifically, before that change, the group permissions were rwx, now when you do a `vagrant up` the permissions are rx, no write. To fix this issue, this is where my change set comes in:

<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/949/1>

To test, please execute `chmod -R 777 ~/.npm/` followed by removing the already installed modules with `rm -rf /fabric/sdk/node/node_modules`. Then try re-running the tests with: `cd fabric` and `make node-sdk-unit-tests`. That change set needs to go in to address what you’re seeing.

<@U1AASP2SJ>  - the good news is there is nothing especially fancy about how TLS communication works between a client and either membersrvc or the peer.   On the client side, it comes down to 2 things:

1) Trusting the TLS server certificate used by membersrvc and/or the peer(s).  This can be done by either explicitly trusting the server certificate or by trusting the root certificate(s) used by the CA which issued the TLS server cert.

2) Determine whether or not you are going to do hostname verification (which of course is the default for TLS client stacks) and in that case you need to ensure that the CN and/or SAN for the TLS server cert used by membersrvs and/or the peer matches the FQDN you use to access it from your client

The chaincode deploy functionality is the SDK is posing two blocking issues for me. My intention is to fix them and contribute back the changes. I wanted to discuss a bit.

The issues center around 
1.   The way the SDK builds go code in the dockerfiles it generates is inconsistent with the way gocode is built in the peer deploy command.(<https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-212>)

2. I think the SDK shouldn't overwrite a Dockerfile in the chaincode directory if one already exists.
sounds good <@U0N13GKRP>
1) we should externalize the dockerfile being used
we also need to look at the change coming to have a "cc" container for golang, java, etc.  <@U0KPFAZNF> should have the details
we can 100% avoid having to vendor fabric with a good cc container which has the fabric src  :wink:
the beginnings of this are already in place, though we are not yet publishing the image to docker
but overall, I still think the SDK needs to be completely out of the Dockerfile business
the deployment should only be a) the code and b) some metadata that conveys what the code needs/expects
and the peer(s) can then map that into the environment properly

Just thinking about what next incremental steps should be.

1. Drop the dockerfile creation from the SDK entirely. ( main issue is then we need to add dockerfiles to the example chaincodes so they are deployable with the SDK) maybe not the end of the world.

2. Conditionally create the dockerfile with the SDK
preferences between 1 and 2
one more thing to consider…. when we enabled user provided names for chaincode, there’ll be less need to involve SDK in any kind of munging of the deployed chaincode (at least to compute name)

We could check to see if one exists in the project or not (if someone wants to override on a per chaincode basis)?  Maybe that is overkill.  Perhaps we just have it as a default template file you could modify and it gt users for all chaincodes?

Just to reiterate, I think dockerfile on the client is not sustainable, and I am moving to get rid of it
<https://lists.hyperledger.org/pipermail/hyperledger-fabric/2016-September/000331.html>
there are numerous problems with this model, the least of which is the weak $arch support in docker
true enough
<@U0KPFAZNF> so we’d just send the chaincode source directly to peer and it’ll cmpute the docker image ?
Oh I see, shuld have read the email link
<@U0KPFAZNF> How would handle deploying something like the utxo example without a provided Dockerfile?
The party that submits the tx seems to be neccessarily responsible for providing a viable dockerfile
It seems reasonable me that Hyperledger networks will specific what $arch are expected for peers
Generally I would say something like the UTXO example would be a candidate for a system chaincode
but, if it were something that was generalizable, it or the resources necessary to support it could be described as a new chaincode platform type
e.g. golang, system (golang), java, c++/utxo, etc
the notion of clients passing in Dockerfiles is problematic on several levels, including robustness (as in the opposite of fragility) which is what is plaguing us right now

but think of it this way: a client has to either specify a _precise_ FROM target, which is fragile w.r.t. $arch, or they have to specify a relative FROM target, which is fragile w.r.t. peer rev/capability
i think this is all wrong: the client has code, and the code has minimum requirements it needs for its environment…that is all we should be specifying
the peer can then map the code/requirements as appropriate
(and note that a network may not necessarily be homogenous
there might be different revs and different $arch
Makes sense to me
frankly I think the whole chaincode model is wrong in terms of even using a base image.  we take a 6MB Go executable and deploy a 1.5GB container
lol true

<@U0PB67X4K>: certainly not ideal, but keep in mind a few things: the majority of the bloat is coming from irreducible components like the golang compiler and JRE.  Also note that docker is relatively efficient with sharing that 1.5G
So, each subsequent instance isn't really 1.5G but much much less
That said, we should try to minimize it as much as possible at some point

<@U0KQ9QKH6> <@U0Z81GL6S> Thanks you. A possible use case for rejection events is to inform the user when his trsnsaction is rejected, and why.  For example, assume someone try to transfer an asset to another user, but transaction is rejected because he is not the currdnt owner of the asset. It would make sense that the client application shows an error message with reason for rejection.

<@U10SJMAHH> : great point and that is exactly what chaincode events are intended to address. The error that you mention is chaincode specific and the chaincode must raise its specific error as a result.
if you look at event-test.js, you should see a test case that sends a chaincode specific event and receives it(parsing its content). let me know if you have any trouble finding or otherwise.

<@U0KQ9QKH6> I’ve just looked at those tests, as I also had the same question. I don’t think that’s enough though. There needs to be a way to tie the received event to the transaction (query/invoke/deploy request) if multiple transactions are in flight. That’s quite difficult as hfc doesn’t seem to expose the transaction ID. Any ideas?

Also - the chaincode is already raising a specific error by returning an error from Query/Invoke/Init. Now the chaincode has to raise it’s specific error twice (once via return to reject the transaction, and again via event to inform the calling application)?

<@U1MSZ37NK> : I'll look into the transaction id issue and get back to you. The chaincode does have the option of returning a error and failing the transaction. Events are not necessarily the used for error conditions.  For instance, they could be used to indicate thresholds being exceeded etc

<@U2P2DHQSJ> It’s not clear to me from what you’re describing how you are setting up your environment and reproducing this. I would recommend to first set up an environment (on v0.6 Fabric + v0.6.4 hfc) to run the peer and memberservices and the chaincode *in development mode*. Meaning, to run your chaincode manually, not deploy it with Docker (network mode). Do this without TLS. This is the simplest use case. Once you get that working, then proceed to having your chaincode deployment in *network mode without TLS*. TLS is the most complicated use case to set up and debug. So please work without TLS for now until you get your basic pipeline working , then add TLS.

Another case which does not work (_but did work earlier with the same branch_) - doing *login-user* from command line (_in a scope of doing chaincode deployment_).

_cd $GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric_

<@U12452RAP> can you clarify your concern? a web application that submits long-running transactions should be designed in such a way that it does the submit and the client code (web browser or mobile app) should immediately mark it as “submitted” or “pending…” indicating that there is going to be update on the status later. and under the cover listens for notifications from the server for status update (websocket, http2 duplex streams, long polling etc.)

the server code (this is the app using the SDK) would register to listen on the event associated with that transaction and upon receiving, send notifications back to the client to update the transaction status.
in the whole process there’s no need to save any state in the server layer (this is the app using the SDK)
<@U12J2D15H> ah ok, so the Proposal class hasn’t been explicitly reviewed yet, it’s a wrapper class on the GRPC message with convenience accessor methods added (set_signature, for instance)
